member.name: P:WixSharp.WixEntity.Attributes
member.summary:
Collection of Attribute/Value pairs for WiX element attributes not supported directly by Wix# objects.
You should use Attributes if you want to inject specific XML attributes for a given WiX element.
For example Hotkey attribute is not supported by Wix# but if you want them to be set in the WiX source file you may achieve this be setting WixEntity.Attributes member variable:
new Shortcut { Attributes= new { {"Hotkey", "0"} }
You can also inject attributes into WiX components "related" to the but not directly represented in the Wix# entities family. For example if you need to set custom attribute for the WiX Component XML element you can use corresponding attributes. The only difference comparing to the Hotkey example is the composite (column separated) key name:
new File { Attributes= new { {"Component:SharedDllRefCount", "yes"} } The code above will force the Wix# compiler to insert "SharedDllRefCount" attribute into Component XML element, which is automatically generated for the .
Currently the only supported "related" attribute is Component.

member.name: P:WixSharp.WixEntity.AttributesDefinition
member.summary:
Optional attributes of the WiX Element (e.g. Secure:YesNoPath).
OptionalAttributes just redirects all access calls to the member.
You can also use to keep the code cleaner.

member.name: M:WixSharp.CommonTasks.Tasks.BuildBootstrapper(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Builds the bootstrapper.
member.param: The prerequisite file.
The primary setup file.
The output (bootsrtapper) file.

The prerequisite registry key value.
This value is used to determine if the PrerequisiteFile should be launched.
This value must comply with the following pattern: <RegistryHive>:<KeyPath>:<ValueName>. PrerequisiteRegKeyValue = @"HKLM:Software\My Company\My Product:Installed"; Existence of the specified registry value at runtime is interpreted as an indication of the PrerequisiteFile has been alreday installed. Thus bootstrapper will execute PrimaryFile without launching PrerequisiteFile first.

The flag which allows you to disable verification of PrerequisiteRegKeyValue after the prerequisite setup is completed.
Normally if bootstrapper checks if PrerequisiteRegKeyValue/> exists straight after the prerequisite installation and starts the primary setup only if it does.
It is possible to instruct bootstrapper to continue with the primary setup regardless of the prerequisite installation outcome. This can be done by setting DoNotPostVerifyPrerequisite to true (default is false)
The optional arguments for the bootstrapper compiler.
member.returns: Path to the built bootstrapper file. Returns null if bootstrapper cannot be built.
member.example:
The following is an example of building bootstrapper Setup.msi for deploying .NET along with the MyProduct.msi file.
WixSharp.CommonTasks.Tasks.BuildBootstrapper( @"C:\downloads\dotnetfx.exe", "MainProduct.msi", "setup.exe", @"HKLM:Software\My Company\My Product:Installed" false, "");

member.name: M:WixSharp.CommonTasks.Tasks.DigitalySign(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Applpies digital signature to a file (e.g. msi, exe, dll) with MS SignTool.exe utility.
member.param: The file to sign.
Specify the signing certificate in a file. If this file is a PFX with a password, the password may be supplied with the password parameter.
The timestamp server's URL. If this option is not present (pass to null), the signed file will not be timestamped. A warning is generated if timestamping fails.
The password to use when opening the PFX file. Should be null if no password required.
The extra arguments to the .
member.returns: Exit code of the SignTool.exe process.
member.example:
The following is an example of signing Setup.msi file.
WixSharp.CommonTasks.Tasks.DigitalySign( "Setup.msi", "MyCert.pfx", "http://timestamp.verisign.com/scripts/timstamp.dll", "MyPassword", null);

member.name: T:WixSharp.CustomUI
member.summary:
Defines custom UI (WiX UI element). This class is to be used to define the customization of the standard MSI UI. The usual scenario of the customization is the injection of the custom into the sequence of the standard dialogs. This can be accomplished by defining the custom dialog as . Such a can be edited with the Visual Studio form designer.
When is complete it can be converted into with the () call. And at compile time Wix# compiler converts into the final WiX UI element XML definition .
While it is possible to construct instance manually it is preferred to use Factory methods of (e.g. BuildPostLicenseDialogUI) for this.
project.UI = WUI.WixUI_Common; project.CustomUI = CustomUIBuilder.BuildPostLicenseDialogUI(productActivationDialog, onNextActions: new DialogAction[]{ new ExecueteCustomAction ("ValidateLicenceKey"), new ShowDialog(Dialogs.InstallDirDlg, "SERIALNUMBER_VALIDATED = \"TRUE\"")});

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.Expand(System.String)
member.summary:
Replaces all Wix# predefined string constants (Environment Constants) in the Wix# directory path with their WiX equivalents and escapes all WiX illegal characters (e.g. space character).
It also replaces all "illegal" characters (e.g. !,\) with '_' character to allow the path value to be used as a WiX Id XML attribute. The following is an example of expanding directory names pathes.
@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product" @"ProgramFilesFolder\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product" @"[ProgramFilesFolder]\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product"
For the list of supported constants analyse WixSharp.Compiler.EnvironmentConstantsMapping.Keys.
member.param: The Wix# directory path.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.ExpandWixEnvConsts(System.String)
member.summary:
Replaces all Wix# predefined string constants (Environment Constants) in the Wix# directory path with their WiX equivalents and escapes all WiX illegal characters (e.g. space character).
The following is an example of expanding directory names pathes.
@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product" @"ProgramFilesFolder\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product" @"[ProgramFilesFolder]\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product"
For the list of supported constants analyse WixSharp.Compiler.EnvironmentConstantsMapping.Keys.
member.param: The Wix# directory path.

member.name: T:WixSharp.ManagedAction
member.summary:
Defines WiX Managed CustomAction.
Managed CustomAction can be defined either in the Wix# script or in the external assembly or C# file. The only requirements for any C# method to be qualified for being Managed CustomAcyion is to have DTF Action signature public static ActionResult MyManagedAction(Session session), and be marked with [CustomAction] attribute.
If Managed CustomAction depends on any assembly, which will not be registered with GAC on the target system such assembly needs to be listed in the .
often needs to be executed with the elevated privileges. Thus after instantiation it will have set to false and set to Execute.deferred to allow elevating.

member.name: T:WixSharp.ExeFileShortcut
member.summary:
Defines to be installed.
is a specialized version of the designed for using as a nested element
There are different ways of defining shortcuts of the Wix# project:
- It can be specified as a nested element of the . In this case after the installation the shortcut will point to the file it belongs to.
- Alternatively the Shortcut can be specified as a nested element. In this case after the installation the shortcut will point to the file will point to the file it belongs to.

member.name: T:WixSharp.LaunchCondition
member.summary:
Defines WiX Condition. Condition is normally associated with CustomActions or WiX elements (e.g. Shortcut).
is nothing else but an XML friendly string wrapper, containing some predefined (commonly used) condition values. You can either use one of the predefined condition values (static members) or define your by specifying full string representation of the required WiX condition when calling the constructor or static method Create.

member.name: M:WixSharp.LaunchCondition.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class. It is made protected to encourage user to use non-default constructor to handle Escape Characters of the value string properly.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with properties/fields initialized with specified parameters
member.param: The value of the WiX condition expression.
The message to be displayed during the installation if evaluated as False.

member.summary: Returns the WiX LaunchCondition as a string.

member.name: M:WixSharp.LaunchCondition.ToCData
member.summary:
Returns the WiX Condition as a . Normally Condition is not designed to be parsed by the XML parser thus it should be embedded as CDATA
<Condition><![CDATA[NETFRAMEWORK20="#0"]]></Condition>
member.returns: A CDATA string representing the condition.

member.name: F:WixSharp.LaunchCondition.Value
member.summary: String value of WiX Condition.

member.name: F:WixSharp.LaunchCondition.Message
member.summary: The message to be displayed during the installation if evaluated as False.

member.name: T:WixSharp.Merge
member.summary:
Defines MergeModule to be embedded into MSI.
Note that WiX syntax allows Merge element to belong to the Product element. However the documentation (WiX v3.0.4917.0) explicitly requires it to be nested inside of the Directory element (even if there is no neither technical nor logical reason for this). Thus Wix# simply follows the WiX convention.

member.name: T:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper
member.summary:
Defines native (un-managed) bootstrapper. The promary usage of is to built bootstrappers for automatically installing .NET for executing MSIs containing managed Custom Actions ().
NativeBootstrapper is a subject to the following limitations:
Only Win32 native bootstrapper can be built.
Only one Prerequisite cen be defined.

member.name: M:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.Build
member.summary: Builds bootstrapper file.
member.returns: Path to the built bootstrapper file. Returns null if bootstrapper cannot be built.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.PrerequisiteFile
member.summary: Gets or sets the prerequisite file.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.PrimaryFile
member.summary: Gets or sets the primary setup file.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.PrerequisiteRegKeyValue
member.summary:
Gets or sets the prerequisite registry key value. This value is used to detrmine if the should be launched.
This value must complay with the following pattern: <RegistryHive>:<KeyPath>:<ValueName>. PrerequisiteRegKeyValue = @"HKLM:Software\My Company\My Product:Installed"; Existance of the sepcified registry value at runtime is interpreted as an indication of the has been alreday installed. Thus bootstrapper will execute without launching first.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.OutputFile
member.summary: Gets or sets the output file (bootsrtapper) name.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.DoNotPostVerifyPrerequisite
member.summary:
Gets or sets the flag which allows you to disable verification of after the prerequisite setup is completed.
Normally if bootstrapper checkes if exists stright after the prerequisite installation and starts the primary setup only if it does.
It is possible to instruct bootstrapper to continue with the primary setup regardless of the prerequisite installation outcome. This can be done by setting DoNotPostVerifyPrerequisite to true (default is false)
member.value: The do not post verify prerequisite.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.OptionalArguments
member.summary: Gets or sets the optional arguments for the bootstrapper compiler.

member.name: T:WixSharp.Binary
member.summary:
Defines binary file to be embedded into MSI (Binary table).
You can use this class to embed any file (e.g. exe, dll, image) to be used in during the installation. Note that none of the binary files are installed on the target system. They are just available at installation time for using CustomActions.
member.example:
The following is an example of embedding CRTSetup.msi file into MSI for further use in InstallCRTAction .
var project = new Project("MyProduct",
new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product", new File(@"readme.txt")), ...
new Binary(@"CRTSetup.msi"), new ManagedAction(@"InstallCRTAction", ...

member.name: T:WixSharp.Compiler
member.summary:
Represents Wix# compiler. This class is responsible for conversion of CLR object into WiX XML source file. allows building complete MSI or WiX source file. It also can prepare WiX source file and generate corresponding batch file for building MSI WiX way: candle.exe + light.exe.
This class contains only static members as it is to be used only for the actual MSI/WXS building operations:

member.name: F:WixSharp.Compiler.AutoGeneration
member.summary: Contains settings for XML auto-generation.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Compiler.LightOptions
member.summary:
WiX linker Light.exe options.
The default value is "-sw1076 -sw1079" (disable warning 1076 and 1079).

member.name: F:WixSharp.Compiler.CandleOptions
member.summary:
WiX compiler Candle.exe options.
The default value is "-sw1076" (disable warning 1026).

member.name: F:WixSharp.Compiler.PreserveTempFiles
member.summary:
Forces to preserve all temporary build files (e.g. *.wxs).
The default value is False: all temporary files are deleted at the end of the build/compilation.
Note: if fails to build MSI the PreserveTempFiles value is ignored and all temporary files are preserved and value

member.name: P:WixSharp.Compiler.WixLocation
member.summary:
Gets or sets the location WiX binaries (compiler/linker/dlls). The default value is a content of environment variable WIXSHARP_WIXDIR.
If user does not set this property explicitly and WIXSHARP_WIXDIR is not defined will try to locate WiX binaries in ProgramFiles\Windows Installer XML v3\bin

member.name: P:WixSharp.Compiler.WixSdkLocation
member.summary:
Gets or sets the location WiX SDK binaries (e.g. MakeSfxCA.exe). The default value is a 'SDK' sub-directory of WixSharp.Compiler.WixLocation directory.
If for whatever reason the default location is invalid you can always set this property to the location of your choice.
member.exception: WiX SDK binaries cannot be found. Please set WixSharp.Compiler.WixSdkLocation to valid path to the Wix SDK binaries.

member.name: T:WixSharp.Condition
member.summary:
Defines WiX Condition. Condition is normally associated with CustomActions or WiX elements (e.g. Shortcut).
is nothing else but an XML friendly string wrapper, containing some predefined (commonly used) condition values. You can either use one of the predefined condition values (static members) or define your by specifying full string representation of the required WiX condition when calling the constructor or static method Create.
member.example:
The following is an example of initializing the Shortcut. with custom value INSTALLDESKTOPSHORTCUT="yes" and the InstalledFileAction. with perefined value NOT_Installed:
var project = new Project("My Product", ... new Dir(@"%Desktop%", new WixSharp.Shortcut("MyApp", "[INSTALL_DIR]MyApp.exe", "") { Condition = new Condition("INSTALLDESKTOPSHORTCUT=\"yes\"") }), new InstalledFileAction("MyApp.exe", "", Return.check, When.After, Step.InstallFinalize, Condition.NOT_Installed), ...

member.name: T:WixSharp.Dir
member.summary:
Defines directory to be installed on target system.
Use this class to define file/directory structure of the deployment solution.
You can use predefined Wix# environment constants for well-known installation locations. They are directly mapped to the corresponding WiX constants:
Wix# - WiX
%WindowsFolder% - [WindowsFolder]
%ProgramFiles% - [ProgramFilesFolder]
%ProgramMenu% - [ProgramMenuFolder]
%AppDataFolder% - [AppDataFolder]
%CommonFilesFolder% - [CommonFilesFolder]
%LocalAppDataFolder% - [LocalAppDataFolder]
%ProgramFiles64Folder% - [ProgramFiles64Folder]
%System64Folder% - [System64Folder]
%SystemFolder% - [SystemFolder]
%TempFolder% - [TempFolder]
%Desktop - [DesktopFolder]

members.member:
Defines all files of a given source directory and subdirectory to be installed on target system.
Use this class to define files to be automatically included into the deployment solution if they name complain with specified wildcard character pattern ().
You can use if it is required to exclude certain files from being included into setup.
This class is a logical equivalent of except it also analyses all files in subdirectories.
Note that all files matching wildcard are resolwed into absolute path thus it may not always be suitable if the Wix# script is to be compiled into WiX XML source only (Compiler.). Though it is not a problem at all if the Wix# script is compiled into MSI file (Compiler.). b The following is an example of defining installation files with wildcard character pattern.
new Project("MyProduct", new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\MyCompany\MyProduct", new Files(@"Release\Bin\*.*"), ...

member.name: T:WixSharp.InstalledFileAction
member.summary: Defines WiX InstalledFileAction for executing installed file.
member.example:
The following is an example of using InstalledFileAction to run installed executable Registrator.exe with different arguments depending in installation type (install/uninstall):
var project = new Project("My Product",
new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product",
new File(binaries, @"AppFiles\MyApp.exe", new WixSharp.Shortcut("MyApp", @"%ProgramMenu%\My Company\My Product"), new WixSharp.Shortcut("MyApp", @"%Desktop%")),
new File(binaries, @"AppFiles\Registrator.exe"),
new InstalledFileAction("Registrator.exe", "", Return.check, When.After, Step.InstallFinalize, Condition.NOT_Installed),
new InstalledFileAction("Registrator.exe", "/u", Return.check, When.Before, Step.InstallFinalize, Condition.Installed), ...
Compiler.BuildMsi(project);

var project = new Project("My Product",

new File(@"AppFiles\Readme.txt"),
new PathFileAction(@"%WindowsFolder%\notepad.exe", "Readme.txt", @"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product", Return.asyncNoWait, When.After, Step.InstallFinalize, Condition.NOT_Installed), ...
Compiler.BuildMsi(project);

member.name: F:WixSharp.Project.UpgradeCode
member.summary:
This is the value of the UpgradeCode attribute of the Wix Product element.
Both WiX and MSI consider this element as optional even it is the only available identifier for defining relationship between different versions of the same product. Wix# in contrary enforces that value to allow any future updates of the product being installed.
If user doesn't specify this value Wix# engine will use as UpgradeCode.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Project.MajorUpgradeStrategy

If you need to implement Major Upgrade define this member to appropriate instance.

member.name: P:WixSharp.Project.GUID
member.summary:
This value uniquely identifies the software product being installed.
All installation scripts for different versions of the same product should have the same . If user doesn't specify this value Wix# engine will generate new random GUID for it.
This value should not be confused with MSI Product.Id, which is in fact not an identifier of the product but rather an identifier of the product particular version. MSI uses UpgradeCode as a common identification of the product regardless of it's version.
In a way is an alias for .

member.name: T:WixSharp.PropertyRef
member.summary:
Defines reference to the Wix custom property.
Sometimes it desirable to access WiX properties defined in the extension modules. is designed for such cases. You can use it as an ordinary WiX property but you do not need to set it up (e.g. define initial value) as it is already done in the corresponding extension module.
In a way PropertyRef is similar to C++ #include as it makes possible to access some entities defined in the external modules.
member.remarks: is inherited from as a recognition their logical relationship and usability pattern but not as their "Parent/Child" nature

member.name: T:WixSharp.Property
member.summary:
Defines WiX custom property.
Traditional property usage involves defining the property by instantiating the class (in the structure) and then setting it from CustomAction (e.g. ).
Property value can be analysed and used in CustomActions or it can be a base for the of item to be installed.

member.name: T:WixSharp.RegValueProperty
member.summary:
Defines WiX custom property assigned by MSI runtime during the installation to the RegistrySearch result.
is used to set property from the registry value when accessing the registry for custom action is inconvenient.
RegistrySearch returns raw data thus data will always contain prefix indicating data type:
DWORD: Starts with '#' optionally followed by '+' or '-'.
REG_BINARY: Starts with '#x' and the installer converts and saves each hexadecimal digit (nibble) as an ASCII character prefixed by '#x'.
REG_EXPAND_SZ: Starts with '#%'.
REG_MULTI_SZ: Starts with '[~]' and ends with '[~]'.
REG_SZ: No prefix, but if the first character of the registry value is '#', the installer escapes the character by prefixing it with another '#'.
member.remarks: In Wix# the preferred way of setting a property value is assigning it from . However may not be an available option if the target system does not have .NET installed. In such cases should be used.
member.example:
The following is an example of installing DotNET Manual.txt file only if .NET v2.0 is installed.
var project = new Project("MyProduct", new Dir(@"%ProgramMenu%\My Company\My Product", new File(@"Files\DotNET Manual.txt") { Condition = new Condition("NETFRAMEWORK20=\"#1\"") }, ... new RegValueProperty("NETFRAMEWORK20", RegistryHive.LocalMachine, @"Software\Microsoft\NET Framework Setup\NDP\v2.0.50727", "Install", "not_defined"),

member.name: T:WixSharp.WebSite
member.summary: This class defines website attributes. It is a close equivalent of WebSite WiX element.

member.name: F:WixSharp.WebSite.Description
member.summary: This is the name of the web site that will show up in the IIS management console.

member.name: F:WixSharp.WebSite.InstallWebSite
member.summary:
Indicates if the WebSite is to be installed (created on IIS) or existing WebSite should be used to install the corresponding WebApplication. The default value is false
Developers should be aware about the WebSite installation model imposed by WiX/MSI and use carefully.
If value is set to false the parent WebApplication () will be installed in the brand new (freshly created) WebSite or in the existing if the one with the same address/port combination already exists on IIS). The undesirable side affect of this deployment scenario is that if the existing WebSite was used to install the WebApplication it will be deleted on IIS during uninstallation even if this WebSite has other WebApplications installed.
The "safer" option is to set value is set to true (default value). In this case the WebApplication will be installed in to existing WebSite with matching address/port. If the match is not found the installation will fail. During the uninstallation only installed WebApplication will be removed from IIS.
